title: اختفاء يفضح زنا محارم “بطله” سلفي
summary: كثيرة هي القضايا الأسرية المثيرة، تبدأ باختفاء وتسجيل بحث لفائدة العائلة، ويزعم المبلغون بأن الأمر له صلة بجرائم اختطاف واحتجاز واغتصاب أو شبكات مختصة في البحث عن الكنوز، لكن الحقيقة تظهر في نهاية المطاف. واقعة تسجيل اختفاء قاصر تبلغ 15 سنة بسيدي الطيبي مع شاب بمحض إرادتها،أكمل القراءة » المقالة اخ…
body: كثيرة هي القضايا الأسرية المثيرة، تبدأ باختفاء وتسجيل بحث لفائدة العائلة، ويزعم المبلغون بأن الأمر له صلة بجرائم اختطاف واحتجاز واغتصاب أو شبكات مختصة في البحث عن الكنوز، لكن الحقيقة تظهر في نهاية المطاف. واقعة تسجيل اختفاء قاصر تبلغ 15 سنة بسيدي الطيبي مع شاب بمحض إرادتها، أكمل القراءة » المقالة اختفاء يفضح زنا محارم “بطله” سلفي fمنشورة على جريدة الصباح .

title: إغلاق قناة "ناصر".. وأسرة عبد الناصر تتحرك لإنقاذ الأرشيف
summary: أقدمت منصة "يوتيوب" على إغلاق قناة "Nasser TV (ناصر تي في)" التي كانت تبث تسجيلات نادرة للرئيس المصري الراحل جمال عبد الناصر، في خطوة أثارت تفاعلًا واسعًا خلال الساعات الماضية، وسط سعي أسرته لاستعادتها أو البحث عن بدائل لنشر باقي تسجيلاته النادرة.

title: Violin therapy: Books in brief
summary:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03226-x

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
body: Nature, Published online: 03 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03226-x Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.

title: These science prizes want to rival the Nobels: how do they compare?
summary:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03118-0

Being named as a Nobel laureate is the ultimate prize for many scientists, but how do other science prizes compare?
body: Nature, Published online: 03 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03118-0 Being named as a Nobel laureate is the ultimate prize for many scientists, but how do other science prizes compare?

title: From tool use to warfare — here are 5 ways Jane Goodall revolutionized our knowledge of chimpanzees
summary: Pioneering primatologist Jane Goodall has died at age 91. These are her five biggest contributions to how we understand about our closest living relatives.

title: Scientists find best evidence yet that icy moon Enceladus is habitable
summary: An ocean flowing beneath the surface of Saturn's moon Enceladus is spewing ice that holds the building blocks of life.

title: Newly discovered comet 'Lemmon' may be visible to the naked eye this month — but it will look more like a lime
summary: Comet Lemmon, discovered earlier this year, will make a close approach to Earth later this month, giving skywatchers the chance to see its surprising lime-green glow.

title: Former Google CEO Will Fund Boat Drones to Explore Rough Antarctic Waters
summary: Scientists have a lot of questions about our planet’s most important carbon sink—and a new project could help answer them.

title: When China makes a climate pledge, the world should listen
summary: Beijing has a track record of only promising what it plans to deliver. But too often the world's attention is elsewhere.

title: Our solar system's asteroid belt is slowly disappearing
summary: A new analysis estimates that the asteroid belt is steadily losing mass each year, and may not be as permanent a feature of the solar system as we thought.

title: The Panama Canal needs a staggering amount of water to operate. Climate change could threaten that, study warns
summary: The vital commercial artery depends on a supply of fresh water to move ships between the two oceans. Drought conditions that were once rare could become common by the end of the century, greatly impacting the canal’s operation.

title: These alien planets are astronomers’ favourites: here’s why
summary:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03220-3

Space scientists look back on 30 years of exoplanet discoveries — from rows of massive ‘super-Earths‘ to worlds with perfectly synchronized orbits.
body: Nature, Published online: 02 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03220-3 Space scientists look back on 30 years of exoplanet discoveries — from rows of massive ‘super-Earths‘ to worlds with perfectly synchronized orbits.

summary:

The primatologist challenged what it meant to be a scientist.
body: Nature, Published online: 02 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03209-y The primatologist challenged what it meant to be a scientist.

body: Nature, Published online: 02 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02898-9 Julie Gould learns of a career-planning framework that can help pinpoint what you love about your current role, and how that can influence future job moves.

summary:

body: Nature, Published online: 02 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02498-7 Confused by research evaluation and its potential impact on career progression? Here are some pointers as to how things work in different parts of the world.

title: Jane Goodall, famed primatologist who discovered chimpanzee tool use, dies at 91
summary: Dame Jane Goodall, the world's preeminent chimpanzee expert, died of natural causes.

title: Bering Land Bridge emerged much later than we thought it did, new study finds
summary: The Bering Land Bridge likely didn't emerge until around 35,000 years ago, much later than was previously thought. This narrows the window of when humans could have crossed over to North America.

title: Yosemite's glaciers have survived 20,000 years — but we could be the first people to see Sierra Nevada ice-free
summary: New research finds the disappearance of glaciers in the Sierra Nevada will be unprecedented in the human history of North America.

title: A 'Great Wave' is rippling through our galaxy, pushing thousands of stars out of place
summary: A giant 'wave' is rippling through the Milky Way, pushing thousands of stars across the galaxy, and scientists don't know what triggered it.

title: The EPA Is Ending Greenhouse Gas Data Collection. Who Will Step Up to Fill the Gap?
summary: With the agency no longer collecting emissions data from polluting companies, attention is turning to whether climate NGOs have the tools—and legal right—to fulfill this EPA function.

title: How to Watch the Orionids Meteor Shower
summary: This long-lasting meteor shower peaks in late October and is known for producing bright “fireball” shooting stars. Here’s what to know about Orionids and other major showers that will appear in 2025.

title: Connecting chemical and protein sequence space to predict biocatalytic reactions
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09519-5

A two-phase machine-learning-based tool making use of high-throughput experimentation is introduced to examine the connections between chemical and protei…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09519-5 A two-phase machine-learning-based tool making use of high-throughput experimentation is introduced to examine the connections between chemical and protein sequence space and predict productive biocatalytic reactions among substrate and enzyme pairs.

title: DNA circuits store data — with heat as their power source
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03202-5

DNA computers can use biological material to perform mathematical functions and store information, but their power sources have been fragile. Researchers …
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03202-5 DNA computers can use biological material to perform mathematical functions and store information, but their power sources have been fragile. Researchers now say they’ve developed a reliable source: heat.

title: Scientists have digitally removed the 'death masks' from four Colombian mummies, revealing their faces for the first time
summary: The reconstructions are based on the skulls of four mummified individuals who had masks tightly fitted on their faces.

title: Tutankhamun quiz: How much do you know about the famous boy king from ancient Egypt?
summary: King Tut's tomb has captivated people worldwide since its discovery in 1922. But how much do you actually know about the boy king? Take our quiz to find out.

title: Stars that brush past black holes live longer, stranger lives after their close encounters with death
summary: A new study shows survivor stars can live billions of years longer than normal, carrying chemical fingerprints of their violent encounters with the Milky Way's black hole.

title: Life-size rock art points the way to oldest human inhabitants of Saudi Arabia — and the desert oases they used
summary: Archaeologists in Saudi Arabia have discovered hundreds of rock art engravings that were carved by humans more than 12,000 years ago.

title: Add a ‘speculation box’ to research papers
summary:
Nature, Published online: 30 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03186-2

Add a ‘speculation box’ to research papers
body: Nature, Published online: 30 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03186-2 Add a ‘speculation box’ to research papers

title: Ancient Egyptian statue of 'Messi' found at Saqqara necropolis is 'only known example of its kind from the Old Kingdom'
summary: A unique statue dating back to the fifth dynasty of ancient Egypt has been discovered at the necropolis of Saqqara.

title: Eagle brooches: 1,500-year-old pins filled with dazzling gems and glass — and worn by powerful Visigoth women
summary: Visigoth women may have worn eagle-shaped pins as a symbol of power.

title: How long does DNA last?
summary: The world's oldest DNA comes from a 2.4 million-year-old ecosystem in Greenland. Will scientists eventually sequence even older DNA?

title: 30,000-year-old 'personal toolkit' found in the Czech Republic provides 'very rare' glimpse into the life of a Stone Age hunter-gatherer
summary: Archaeologists have found an extraordinary cluster of Stone Age artifacts that may have been the personal gear of a single prehistoric individual.

title: James Webb Space Telescope reveals thick cosmic dust of Sagittarius B2, the most enormous star-forming cloud in the Milky Way — Space photo of the week
summary: The James Webb Space Telescope has uncovered dazzling newborn stars and thick cosmic dust in Sagittarius B2, the Milky Way's most enormous star-forming cloud.

title: Science history: Rosetta stone is deciphered, opening a window into ancient Egyptian civilization — Sept. 27, 1822
summary: On Sept. 27, 1822, French philologist Jean-François Champollion announced that he had deciphered ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics, using the Rosetta stone. This ushered in a new craze for Egyptology and helped us understand one of the world's longest-running civilizations.

title: أوروبا تبحث تحديث قواعد ملفات الارتباط لتسهيل التصفح
summary: تسعى المفوضية الأوروبية إلى جعل تصفح الإنترنت أكثر سهولة، عبر تخفيف قواعد الخصوصية، وإيجاد طريقة جديدة لإدارة ملفات الارتباط (الكوكيز).

title: جوائز "نوبل" الساخرة تكرّم أصحاب أغرب البحوث والاختراعات
summary: حصلت اختراعات من بينها طلاء الأبقار بخطوط الحمير الوحشية لإبعاد الذباب عنها، وطهو الصلصة الإيطالية من دون تكوّن كِتل، على مكافآت نسخة ساخرة من جوائز "نوبل"، تحتفي بالبحث العلمي ولكن بطريقة مرحة.

title: شهادة مدير "إف بي آي" تحسم قضية إبستين.. ماذا قال؟
summary: أكد مدير مكتب التحقيقات الفدرالي "إف بي آي"، كاش باتيل، الثلاثاء، أنه لا توجد "معلومات موثوقة" في الملفات القضائية تشير إلى أن الممول الثري جيفري إبستين، المدان بجرائم جنسية، وفّر فتيات قاصرات لأشخاص آخرين.

title: فجر الجمعة.. سماء مكة تشهد ظاهرة فلكية مهيبة
summary: تشهد سماء مكة المكرمة في غرب السعودية فجر الجمعة ظاهرة تعامد القمر الأحدب المتناقص على الكعبة المشرفة في حدث فلكي يجمع بين الدقة العلمية والجمال البصري، ويعكس التناغم بين حركة الأجرام السماوية والمواقع الأرضية.
